name: The Otherworld
shortDescription: Parallel realm of gods, spirits, and the dead, accessible through sidhe mounds, caves, and over water
fullDescription: The Otherworld (Irish: An Saol Eile, Aos S√≠) is the parallel realm in Celtic mythology inhabited by the Tuatha D√© Danann, spirits, and the dead. It exists alongside the mortal world but is normally invisible and inaccessible except through specific gateways: sidhe mounds, sacred wells, caves, or by traveling over water to mystical islands. Time flows differently there, and it contains numerous sub-realms including T√≠r na n√ìg, Mag Mell, and Tech Duinn. The Otherworld is not strictly an afterlife but a place where gods, ancestors, and mortals can potentially interact.

geography.location: Coexistent with mortal world, accessed through liminal spaces

mythologyContexts.usage: General term for the supernatural realm where gods, fairies, and ancestors dwell. Serves as the source of magic, wisdom, and divine intervention in mortal affairs. Mortals can visit but must be careful of time distortion and the danger of being unable to return

textReferences.context: Genre of tales describing voyages to otherworld islands
Genre of tales describing adventures in the otherworld

textReferences.passage: The Wasting Sickness of C√∫ Chulainn
textReferences.context: C√∫ Chulainn visits the otherworld and fights for the s√≠dhe

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Represents the unconscious mind, the realm of archetypes and eternal truths, the source of inspiration and magic. The permeable boundary between worlds symbolizes the Celtic understanding that the sacred and mundane interpenetrate. Time distortion represents the timeless quality of spiritual experience.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The Otherworld is central to Celtic cosmology, influencing later concepts of fairyland, the afterlife, and magical realms throughout European folklore. It reflects a non-dualistic spirituality where the supernatural is ever-present but hidden. The concept influenced medieval romance, Arthurian legend, and modern fantasy literature.

sources.passage: The Wasting Sickness of C√∫ Chulainn

linguistic.originalScript: Old Irish: An Saol Eile (The Other Life), T√≠r Tairngire (Land of Promise), Aos S√≠ (People of the Mounds)

etymology.meaning: The Other World, Realm of the S√≠dhe
etymology.derivation: Irish saol (life, world) + eile (other). S√≠dhe from Proto-Celtic *sƒìdos (seat, mound). T√≠r Tairngire from t√≠r (land) + tairngire (promised). Generic term for parallel spiritual realm

originPoint.name: Pan-Celtic otherworld concept
originPoint.description: Universal Celtic concept of parallel spiritual realm. Accessible through: sidhe mounds, sacred wells, stone circles, western sea voyages, liminal times (Samhain). Not a geographic location but a coexistent metaphysical dimension

firstAttestation.description: Extensive otherworld descriptions in immrama (voyages), echtra (adventures), and mythological cycles. Pre-Christian oral tradition codified in Early Medieval manuscripts

temporal.timelinePosition: La T√®ne period (450-1 BCE) Celtic cosmology formation, Roman Celtic period (1-400 CE), Early Medieval Ireland (400-800 CE) literary codification
temporal.culturalPeriod: Iron Age Celtic through Medieval period
